Dataset | Current Population Survey | …the census hot deck procedures assume either no response bias or "ignorable response bias" whereby the match criteria capture differences in earnings. For example, the likelihood of nonresponse might vary with schooling, occupation, and other match attributes, but as long as the earnings of respondents and nonrespondents within cells are equivalent, there is no response bias resulting from the imputation procedure. | [('…the', 'JJ'), ('census', 'NN'), ('hot', 'JJ'), ('deck', 'NN'), ('procedures', 'NNS'), ('assume', 'VBP'), ('either', 'DT'), ('no', 'DT'), ('response', 'NN'), ('bias', 'NN'), ('or', 'CC'), ('``', '``'), ('ignorable', 'JJ'), ('response', 'NN'), ('bias', 'NN'), ("''", "''"), ('whereby', 'VBZ'), ('the', 'DT'), ('match', 'NN'), ('criteria', 'NNS'), ('capture', 'NN'), ('differences', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('earnings', 'NNS'), ('.', '.'), ('For', 'IN'), ('example', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('the', 'DT'), ('likelihood', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('nonresponse', 'NN'), ('might', 'MD'), ('vary', 'VB'), ('with', 'IN'), ('schooling', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('occupation', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('other', 'JJ'), ('match', 'NN'), ('attributes', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('but', 'CC'), ('as', 'RB'), ('long', 'RB'), ('as', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('earnings', 'NNS'), ('of', 'IN'), ('respondents', 'NNS'), ('and', 'CC'), ('nonrespondents', 'NNS'), ('within', 'IN'), ('cells', 'NNS'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('equivalent', 'JJ'), (',', ','), ('there', 'EX'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('no', 'DT'), ('response', 'NN'), ('bias', 'NN'), ('resulting', 'VBG'), ('from', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('imputation', 'NN'), ('procedure', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Current Population Survey | …although the "cell hot deck" procedure has been used for the CPS-ORG files since their beginning in 1979, the selection categories have not been identical over time. Prior to 1994, there were six usual hours worked categories and thus 11,232 cells. Beginning in 1994, usual work hours could be reported as "variables." Two additional hours cells were added for workers reporting variable hours, one for those who usually work full time and one for those who usually work part time. | [('…although', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('``', '``'), ('cell', 'NN'), ('hot', 'JJ'), ('deck', 'NN'), ("''", "''"), ('procedure', 'NN'), ('has', 'VBZ'), ('been', 'VBN'), ('used', 'VBN'), ('for', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('CPS-ORG', 'NNP'), ('files', 'NNS'), ('since', 'IN'), ('their', 'PRP$'), ('beginning', 'NN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('1979', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('the', 'DT'), ('selection', 'NN'), ('categories', 'NNS'), ('have', 'VBP'), ('not', 'RB'), ('been', 'VBN'), ('identical', 'JJ'), ('over', 'IN'), ('time', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('Prior', 'RB'), ('to', 'TO'), ('1994', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('there', 'EX'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('six', 'CD'), ('usual', 'JJ'), ('hours', 'NNS'), ('worked', 'VBN'), ('categories', 'NNS'), ('and', 'CC'), ('thus', 'RB'), ('11,232', 'CD'), ('cells', 'NNS'), ('.', '.'), ('Beginning', 'VBG'), ('in', 'IN'), ('1994', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('usual', 'JJ'), ('work', 'NN'), ('hours', 'NNS'), ('could', 'MD'), ('be', 'VB'), ('reported', 'VBN'), ('as', 'IN'), ('``', '``'), ('variables', 'NNS'), ('.', '.'), ("''", "''"), ('Two', 'CD'), ('additional', 'JJ'), ('hours', 'NNS'), ('cells', 'NNS'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('added', 'VBN'), ('for', 'IN'), ('workers', 'NNS'), ('reporting', 'VBG'), ('variable', 'JJ'), ('hours', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('one', 'CD'), ('for', 'IN'), ('those', 'DT'), ('who', 'WP'), ('usually', 'RB'), ('work', 'VBP'), ('full', 'JJ'), ('time', 'NN'), ('and', 'CC'), ('one', 'CD'), ('for', 'IN'), ('those', 'DT'), ('who', 'WP'), ('usually', 'RB'), ('work', 'VBP'), ('part', 'NN'), ('time', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | Current Population Survey | …the CPS-ORG earnings files made available to researchers are prepared by the U.S. Census for use by the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), which then makes these files available to the research community. The information provided on the BLS's CPS earnings files regarding allocated earnings has varied in important ways over time. Figures are compiled for all employed wage and salary workers ages 16 and over with reported positive usual weekly earnings (weekly earnings designated as missing are retained for 1973-1978). Dataset | Current Population Survey | …the 1973-1978 May CPS earnings files formed the basis for much early research on labor unions and industry differentials, among other topics. On these files, individuals who do not report earnings are included but weekly earnings are listed as missing. Hence, researchers using the May 1973-78 CPS to estimate wage equations, knowingly or unkowingly, exclude allocated earners. During the 1973-78 period, the percentage of wage and salary workers whose weekly earnings are missing ranges between 18% and 22%. These are primarily workers who did not report earnings. | [('…the', 'JJ'), ('1973-1978', 'JJ'), ('May', 'NNP'), ('CPS', 'NNP'), ('earnings', 'NNS'), ('files', 'NNS'), ('formed', 'VBD'), ('the', 'DT'), ('basis', 'NN'), ('for', 'IN'), ('much', 'JJ'), ('early', 'JJ'), ('research', 'NN'), ('on', 'IN'), ('labor', 'NN'), ('unions', 'NNS'), ('and', 'CC'), ('industry', 'NN'), ('differentials', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('among', 'IN'), ('other', 'JJ'), ('topics', 'NNS'), ('.', '.'), ('On', 'IN'), ('these', 'DT'), ('files', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('individuals', 'NNS'), ('who', 'WP'), ('do', 'VBP'), ('not', 'RB'), ('report', 'VB'), ('earnings', 'NNS'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('included', 'VBN'), ('but', 'CC'), ('weekly', 'JJ'), ('earnings', 'NNS'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('listed', 'VBN'), ('as', 'IN'), ('missing', 'VBG'), ('.', '.'), ('Hence', 'NNP'), (',', ','), ('researchers', 'NNS'), ('using', 'VBG'), ('the', 'DT'), ('May', 'NNP'), ('1973-78', 'JJ'), ('CPS', 'NNP'), ('to', 'TO'), ('estimate', 'VB'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('equations', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('knowingly', 'RB'), ('or', 'CC'), ('unkowingly', 'RB'), (',', ','), ('exclude', 'RB'), ('allocated', 'JJ'), ('earners', 'NNS'), ('.', '.'), ('During', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('1973-78', 'JJ'), ('period', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('the', 'DT'), ('percentage', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('and', 'CC'), ('salary', 'JJ'), ('workers', 'NNS'), ('whose', 'WP$'), ('weekly', 'JJ'), ('earnings', 'NNS'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('missing', 'VBG'), ('ranges', 'NNS'), ('between', 'IN'), ('18', 'CD'), ('%', 'NN'), ('and', 'CC'), ('22', 'CD'), ('%', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('These', 'DT'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('primarily', 'RB'), ('workers', 'NNS'), ('who', 'WP'), ('did', 'VBD'), ('not', 'RB'), ('report', 'VB'), ('earnings', 'NNS'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | Current Population Survey | …beginning in January 1989, earnings allocation flags included in the CPS-ORG are unreliable. They designate about 4% of workers as having imputed earnings, which is roughly a quarter of those who in fact had their earnings allocated. An alternative method exists to identify allocated earners. The ORG files during these years contain an "unedited" weekly earnings variable. Those with missing unedited weekly earnings (and valid edited weekly earnings) are designated as having earnings allocated. Those with non-missing unedited earnings are assumed to have been earnings respondents. This method appears to provide a reliable measure of non-response for most workers. | [('…beginning', 'VBG'), ('in', 'IN'), ('January', 'NNP'), ('1989', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('earnings', 'NNS'), Dataset | Current Population Survey | …following CPS revisions in 1994, there were no usable earnings allocation flags in the CPS-ORG files for January 1994 through August 1995. The series of questions used by the census to form the "edited" usual weekly earnings field became more complex following the 1994 CPS redesign. if a response is missing or replaced on any part of the sequence of questions, the census utilizes its imputation procedure. Although procedures have been consistent since 1994, there has been a clear and worisome increase in nonresponse since 1998 with the nonresponse rate in 2001 being 31%. | [('…following', 'VBG'), ('CPS', 'NNP'), ('revisions', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('1994', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('there', 'EX'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('no', 'DT'), ('usable', 'JJ'), ('earnings', 'NNS'), ('allocation', 'NN'), ('flags', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('CPS-ORG', 'NNP'), ('files', 'NNS'), ('for', 'IN'), ('January', 'NNP'), ('1994', 'CD'), ('through', 'IN'), ('August', 'NNP'), ('1995', 'CD'), ('.', '.'), ('The', 'DT'), ('series', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('questions', 'NNS'), ('used', 'VBN'), ('by', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('census', 'NN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('form', 'VB'), ('the', 'DT'), ('``', '``'), ('edited', 'JJ'), ("''", "''"), ('usual', 'JJ'), ('weekly', 'JJ'), ('earnings', 'NNS'), ('field', 'NN'), ('became', 'VBD'), ('more', 'RBR'), ('complex', 'JJ'), ('following', 'VBG'), ('the', 'DT'), ('1994', 'CD'), ('CPS', 'NNP'), ('redesign', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('if', 'IN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('response', 'NN'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('missing', 'VBG'), ('or', 'CC'), ('replaced', 'VBN'), ('on', 'IN'), ('any', 'DT'), ('part', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('sequence', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('questions', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('the', 'DT'), ('census', 'NN'), ('utilizes', 'VBZ'), ('its', 'PRP$'), ('imputation', 'NN'), ('procedure', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('Although', 'IN'), ('procedures', 'NNS'), ('have', 'VBP'), ('been', 'VBN'), ('consistent', 'JJ'), ('since', 'IN'), ('1994', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('there', 'EX'), ('has', 'VBZ'), ('been', 'VBN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('clear', 'JJ'), ('and', 'CC'), ('worisome', 'JJ'), ('increase', 'NN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('nonresponse', 'JJ'), ('since', 'IN'), ('1998', 'CD'), ('with', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('nonresponse', 'JJ'), ('rate', 'NN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('2001', 'CD'), ('being', 'VBG'), ('31', 'CD'), ('%', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | Survey of Health, Ageing, and Retirement in Europe | …a number of measures were taken to improve survey quality and to improve immediate comparison to the administrative variables; according to Hurd et al. (2004), one way to increase the quality of report is by giving respondents the opportunity to report income in a time span consistent with how they receive their income, for example, instead of forcing respondents to provide a yearly amount for earnings and pensions, they were given the possibility to report these amounts either per month or per year. | [('…a', 'JJ'), ('number', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('measures', 'NNS'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('taken', 'VBN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('improve', 'VB'), ('survey', 'NN'), ('quality', 'NN'), ('and', 'CC'), ('to', 'TO'), ('improve', 'VB'), ('immediate', 'JJ'), ('comparison', 'NN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('the', 'DT'), ('administrative', 'JJ'), ('variables', 'NNS'), (';', ':'), ('according', 'VBG'), ('to', 'TO'), ('Hurd', 'NNP'), ('et', 'FW'), ('al', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('(', '('), ('2004', 'CD'), (')', ')'), (',', ','), ('one', 'CD'), ('way', 'NN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('increase', 'VB'), ('the', 'DT'), ('quality', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('report', 'NN'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('by', 'IN'), ('giving', 'VBG'), ('respondents', 'NNS'), ('the', 'DT'), ('opportunity', 'NN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('report', 'VB'), ('income', 'NN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('time', 'NN'), ('span', 'JJ'), ('consistent', 'NN'), ('with', 'IN'), ('how', 'WRB'), ('they', 'PRP'), ('receive', 'VBP'), ('their', 'PRP$'), ('income', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('for', 'IN'), ('example', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('instead', 'RB'), ('of', 'IN'), ('forcing', 'VBG'), ('respondents', 'NNS'), ('to', 'TO'), ('provide', 'VB'), ('a', 'DT'), ('yearly', 'JJ'), ('amount', 'NN'), ('for', 'IN'), ('earnings', 'NNS'), ('and', 'CC'), ('pensions', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('they', 'PRP'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('given', 'VBN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('possibility', 'NN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('report', 'VB'), ('these', 'DT'), ('amounts', 'NNS'), ('either', 'CC'), ('per', 'JJ'), ('month', 'NN'), ('or', 'CC'), ('per', 'IN'), ('year', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | CPS/SSR 1979 | …to solve the identification problem researchers require the presence of an auxiliary data-set which is used to estimate the parameter of interest. In this paper researchers use auxiliary data to mean a random sample of mismeasured and true variables which may or may not come from the same distriburtion as the primary data. In the case where the additional data are randomly sampled from the population, the auxiliary data-set becomes a validation data-set. More importantly, the auxiliary data can also be a random sample of variables where the marginal distribution of the conditional variable in the auxiliary data is different from the marginal distribution of the conditional variable in the primary sample. | [('…to', 'NN'), ('solve', 'VB'), ('the', 'DT'), ('identification', 'NN'), ('problem', 'NN'), ('researchers', 'NNS'), ('require', Dataset | Current Population Survey | …if in addition to Assumption 1 researchers have that the marginal density of the proxy variable in the auxiliary data is equal to the marginal density of the proxy variable in the primary data, then the marginal density of the latent variable in both data-sets equal each other. Dataset | CPS/SSR 1979 | …another shortcoming of the SSR data is that earnings are capped at the social security maximum of $16,500. This map into a censoring level of 40% for males and about 4% for females. To reduce the effect of sample selection that would arise using the female samples, researchers use the male sample and restrict it to individual between the ages of 40 and 50 (for computational simplicity) and use censored least absolute deviation estimators to deal with censoring. (1999) is a cause of concern for measuring labor's share because the hourly wage series derived from the National Income and Product Accounts data shows significantly faster growth than all other available series. | [('…the', 'JJ'), ('divergent', 'NN'), ('trends', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('various', 'JJ'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('series', 'NN'), ('documented', 'VBN'), ('by', 'IN'), ('Katharine', 'NNP'), ('Abraham', 'NNP'), ('et', 'FW'), ('al', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('(', '('), ('1999', 'CD'), (')', ')'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('a', 'DT'), ('cause', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('concern', 'NN'), ('for', 'IN'), ('measuring', 'VBG'), ('labor', 'NN'), ("'s", 'POS'), ('share', 'NN'), ('because', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('hourly', 'JJ'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('series', 'NN'), ('derived', 'VBN'), ('from', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('National', 'NNP'), ('Income', 'NNP'), ('and', 'CC'), ('Product', 'NNP'), ('Accounts', 'NNP'), ('data', 'NN'), ('shows', 'NNS'), ('significantly', 'RB'), ('faster', 'RBR'), ('growth', 'NN'), ('than', 'IN'), ('all', 'DT'), ('other', 'JJ'), ('available', 'JJ'), ('series', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | National Income and Product Accounts | …external literature from Abraham et al. (1999) find that half of the divergence between earnings from the Current Population Survey and this data between 1973 and 1997 is due to differential hours growth, and half is due to differential growth in total payroll; in turn, if National Income Product Accounts data overstate the growth in payroll, then labor's share is overstated as well. | [('…external', 'JJ'), ('literature', 'NN'), ('from', 'IN'), ('Abraham', 'NNP'), ('et', 'CC'), ('al', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('(', '('), ('1999', 'CD'), (')', ')'), ('find', 'VBP'), ('that', 'IN'), ('half', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('divergence', 'NN'), ('between', 'IN'), ('earnings', 'NNS'), ('from', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('Current', 'NNP'), ('Population', 'NNP'), ('Survey', 'NNP'), ('and', 'CC'), ('this', 'DT'), ('data', 'NN'), ('between', 'IN'), ('1973', 'CD'), ('and', 'CC'), ('1997', 'CD'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('due', 'JJ'), ('to', 'TO'), ('differential', 'JJ'), ('hours', 'NNS'), ('growth', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('half', 'NN'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('due', 'JJ'), ('to', 'TO'), ('differential', 'JJ'), ('growth', 'NN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('total', 'JJ'), ('payroll', 'NN'), (';', ':'), ('in', 'IN'), ('turn', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('if', 'IN'), ('National', 'NNP'), ('Income', 'NNP'), ('Product', 'NNP'), ('Accounts', 'NNP'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('overstate', 'VBP'), ('the', 'DT'), ('growth', 'NN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('payroll', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('then', 'RB'), ('labor', 'NN'), ("'s", 'POS'), ('share', 'NN'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('overstated', 'VBN'), ('as', 'RB'), ('well', 'RB'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | National Longitudinal Survey of Youth | …the NLSY is based on a nationally representative sample of about 6,000 persons who were 14 to 22 years old in 1979. These youngs and young adults were reinterviewed once a year until 1994 and once every other year thereafter. The final year of data available for this study is 1996, when the interviewees were 31 to 39 years old. | [('…the', 'JJ'), ('NLSY', 'NNP'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('based', 'VBN'), ('on', 'IN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('nationally', 'RB'), ('representative', 'JJ'), ('sample', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('about', 'IN'), ('6,000', 'CD'), ('persons', 'NNS'), ('who', 'WP'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('14', 'CD'), ('to', 'TO'), ('22', 'CD'), ('years', 'NNS'), ('old', 'JJ'), ('in', 'IN'), ('1979', 'CD'), ('.', '.'), ('These', 'DT'), ('youngs', 'NNS'), ('and', 'CC'), ('young', 'JJ'), ('adults', 'NNS'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('reinterviewed', 'VBN'), ('once', 'RB'), ('a', 'DT'), ('year', 'NN'), ('until', 'IN'), ('1994', 'CD'), ('and', 'CC'), ('once', 'RB'), ('every', 'DT'), ('other', 'JJ'), ('year', 'NN'), ('thereafter', 'RB'), ('.', '.'), ('The', 'DT'), ('final', 'JJ'), ('year', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('available', 'JJ'), ('for', 'IN'), ('this', 'DT'), ('study', 'NN'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('1996', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('when', 'WRB'), ('the', 'DT'), ('interviewees', 'NNS'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('31', 'CD'), ('to', 'TO'), ('39', 'CD'), ('years', 'NNS'), ('old', 'JJ'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | National Longitudinal Survey of Youth | …given that the NLSY is a general-purpose survey intended to be representative of an entire cohort, the experiences of sample members varied widely. For example, some members of the sample did not complete even high school, while others completed not only high school, but various levels of higher education. Some individuals in the NLSY remained in the same state throughout their lives, while others showed considerable geographic mobility. | [('…given', 'RB'), ('that', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('NLSY', 'NNP'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('a', 'DT'), ('general-purpose', 'JJ'), ('survey', 'NN'), ('intended', 'VBD'), ('to', 'TO'), ('be', 'VB'), ('representative', 'JJ'), ('of', 'IN'), ('an', 'DT'), ('entire', 'JJ'), ('cohort', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('the', 'DT'), ('experiences', 'NNS'), ('of', 'IN'), ('sample', 'JJ'), ('members', 'NNS'), ('varied', 'VBD'), ('widely', 'RB'), ('.', '.'), ('For', 'IN'), ('example', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('some', 'DT'), ('members', 'NNS'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('sample', 'NN'), ('did', 'VBD'), ('not', 'RB'), ('complete', 'VB'), ('even', 'RB'), ('high', 'JJ'), ('school', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('while', 'IN'), ('others', 'NNS'), ('completed', 'VBD'), ('not', 'RB'), ('only', 'RB'), ('high', 'JJ'), ('school', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('but', 'CC'), ('various', 'JJ'), ('levels', 'NNS'), ('of', 'IN'), ('higher', 'JJR'), ('education', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('Some', 'DT'), ('individuals', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('NLSY', 'NNP'), ('remained', 'VBD'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('same', 'JJ'), ('state', 'NN'), ('throughout', 'IN'), ('their', 'PRP$'), ('lives', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('while', 'IN'), ('others', 'NNS'), ('showed', 'VBD'), ('considerable', 'JJ'), ('geographic', 'JJ'), ('mobility', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | National Longitudinal Survey of Youth | …many of those surveyed in the NLSY made long-distance moves at some point in their lives. According to the top panel, 38.9% of all sample members were in a different state in 1996 than at birth, and 25.5% were in a different state than when they were first observed in 1979. The middle panel indicates migration to a noncontiguous state, and the bottom panel indicates migration to another Census division. Depending on the specific time period, about two-thirds to three-quarters of interstate moves were to a noncontiguous state or to a different Census division. | [('…many', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('those', 'DT'), ('surveyed', 'VBN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('NLSY', 'NNP'), ('made', 'VBD'), ('long-distance', 'NN'), ('moves', 'NNS'), ('at', 'IN'), ('some', 'DT'), ('point', 'NN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('their', 'PRP$'), ('lives', 'NNS'), ('.', '.'), ('According', 'VBG'), ('to', 'TO'), ('the', 'DT'), ('top', 'JJ'), ('panel', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('38.9', 'CD'), ('%', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('all', 'DT'), ('sample', 'JJ'), ('members', 'NNS'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('in', 'IN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('different', 'JJ'), ('state', 'NN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('1996', 'CD'), ('than', 'IN'), ('at', 'IN'), ('birth', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('25.5', 'CD'), ('%', 'NN'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('in', 'IN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('different', 'JJ'), ('state', 'NN'), ('than', 'IN'), ('when', 'WRB'), ('they', 'PRP'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('first', 'RB'), ('observed', 'VBN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('1979', 'CD'), ('.', '.'), ('The', 'DT'), ('middle', 'JJ'), ('panel', 'NN'), ('indicates', 'VBZ'), ('migration', 'NN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('a', 'DT'), ('noncontiguous', 'JJ'), ('state', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('the', 'DT'), ('bottom', 'JJ'), ('panel', 'NN'), ('indicates', 'VBZ'), ('migration', 'NN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('another', 'DT'), ('Census', 'NNP'), ('division', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('Depending', 'VBG'), ('on', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('specific', 'JJ'), ('time', 'NN'), ('period', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('about', 'RB'), ('two-thirds', 'NNS'), ('to', 'TO'), ('three-quarters', 'NNS'), ('of', 'IN'), ('interstate', 'JJ'), ('moves', 'NNS'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('to', 'TO'), ('a', 'DT'), ('noncontiguous', 'JJ'), ('state', 'NN'), ('or', 'CC'), ('to', 'TO'), ('a', 'DT'), ('different', 'JJ'), ('Census', 'NNP'), ('division', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | Current Population Survey | …annual supplements to the Current Population Survye (CPS) provide information on moves since the previous year for a total of about 50,000 to 60,000 households. Because of the methods used to rotate households in and out of the survey, migration patters for many of these households can actually be observed over a two-year time frame. Even so, the information tends to be less useful for college students and recent colege graduates than for most other adults. This is because the CPS refers to permanent residence, which may differ from residence while attending school or while in a temporary job. | [('…annual', 'JJ'), ('supplements', 'NNS'), ('to', 'TO'), ('the', 'DT'), ('Current', 'NNP'), ('Population', 'NNP'), ('Survye', 'NNP'), ('(', '('), ('CPS', 'NNP'), (')', ')'), ('provide', 'VBP'), ('information', 'NN'), ('on', 'IN'), ('moves', 'NNS'), ('since', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('previous', 'JJ'), ('year', 'NN'), ('for', 'IN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('total', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('about', 'RB'), ('50,000', 'CD'), ('to', 'TO'), ('60,000', 'CD'), ('households', 'NNS'), ('.', '.'), ('Because', 'IN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('methods', 'NNS'), ('used', 'VBN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('rotate', 'VB'), ('households', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('and', 'CC'), ('out', 'IN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('survey', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('migration', 'NN'), ('patters', 'NNS'), ('for', 'IN'), ('many', 'JJ'), ('of', 'IN'), ('these', 'DT'), ('households', 'NNS'), ('can', 'MD'), ('actually', 'RB'), ('be', 'VB'), ('observed', 'VBN'), ('over', 'IN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('two-year', 'JJ'), ('time', 'NN'), ('frame', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('Even', 'RB'), ('so', 'RB'), (',', ','), ('the', 'DT'), ('information', 'NN'), ('tends', 'VBZ'), ('to', 'TO'), ('be', 'VB'), ('less', 'RBR'), ('useful', 'JJ'), ('for', 'IN'), ('college', 'NN'), ('students', 'NNS'), ('and', 'CC'), ('recent', 'JJ'), ('colege', 'NN'), ('graduates', 'NNS'), ('than', 'IN'), ('for', 'IN'), ('most', 'JJS'), ('other', 'JJ'), ('adults', 'NNS'), ('.', '.'), ('This', 'DT'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('because', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('CPS', 'NNP'), ('refers', 'NNS'), ('to', 'TO'), ('permanent', 'JJ'), ('residence', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('which', 'WDT'), ('may', 'MD'), ('differ', 'VB'), ('from', 'IN'), ('residence', 'NN'), ('while', 'IN'), ('attending', 'VBG'), ('school', 'NN'), ('or', 'CC'), ('while', 'IN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('temporary', 'JJ'), ('job', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | Current Population Survey | …college graduate pay relative to the national average was constructed using March Current Population Survey estimates for earnings for full-time, full-year workers divided by the number of hours worked. Dataset | Current Population Survey | …multiple Current Population Survey cross-section data are considered when using the Outgoing Rotation Group samples from two months in which it is assumed that a steady state equilibrium (approximately) holds in each and where the minimum wages are different, with the earlier period having a minimum wage less than the later one; all primitive parameters are assumed to be identical in the two months. | [('…multiple', 'JJ'), ('Current', 'NNP'), ('Population', 'NNP'), ('Survey', 'NNP'), ('cross-section', 'NN'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('considered', 'VBN'), ('when', 'WRB'), ('using', 'VBG'), ('the', 'DT'), ('Outgoing', 'NNP'), ('Rotation', 'NNP'), ('Group', 'NNP'), ('samples', 'VBZ'), ('from', 'IN'), ('two', 'CD'), ('months', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('which', 'WDT'), ('it', 'PRP'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('assumed', 'VBN'), ('that', 'IN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('steady', 'JJ'), ('state', 'NN'), ('equilibrium', 'NN'), ('(', '('), ('approximately', 'RB'), (')', ')'), ('holds', 'VBZ'), ('in', 'IN'), ('each', 'DT'), ('and', 'CC'), ('where', 'WRB'), ('the', 'DT'), ('minimum', 'NN'), ('wages', 'NNS'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('different', 'JJ'), (',', ','), ('with', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('earlier', 'JJR'), ('period', 'NN'), ('having', 'VBG'), ('a', 'DT'), ('minimum', 'JJ'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('less', 'JJR'), ('than', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('later', 'JJ'), ('one', 'CD'), (';', ':'), ('all', 'DT'), ('primitive', 'JJ'), ('parameters', 'NNS'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('assumed', 'VBN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('be', 'VB'), ('identical', 'JJ'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('two', 'CD'), ('months', 'NNS'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Current Population Survey | …when there exists data from two ORG Current Population Surveys in which data outcomes are generated from steady state equilibrium behavior associated with two values of the minimum wage, a Cobb-Douglas matching function parameter and the cost of a vacancy can be consistently estimated if estimates of a function of other primitive parameters at the two equilibrium values satisfy a condition that restricts the estimator of the Cobb-Douglas parameters to the unit interval. | [('…when', 'NN'), ('there', 'EX'), ('exists', 'VBZ'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('from', 'IN'), ('two', 'CD'), ('ORG', 'NNP'), ('Current', 'NNP'), ('Population', 'NNP'), ('Surveys', 'NNP'), ('in', 'IN'), ('which', 'WDT'), ('data', 'NN'), ('outcomes', 'NNS'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('generated', 'VBN'), ('from', 'IN'), ('steady', 'JJ'), ('state', 'NN'), ('equilibrium', 'NN'), ('behavior', 'NN'), ('associated', 'VBN'), ('with', 'IN'), ('two', 'CD'), ('values', 'NNS'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('minimum', 'JJ'), ('wage', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('a', 'DT'), ('Cobb-Douglas', 'JJ'), ('matching', 'NN'), ('function', 'NN'), ('parameter', 'NN'), ('and', 'CC'), ('the', 'DT'), ('cost', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('vacancy', 'NN'), ('can', 'MD'), ('be', 'VB'), ('consistently', 'RB'), ('estimated', 'VBN'), ('if', 'IN'), ('estimates', 'NNS'), ('of', 'IN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('function', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('other', 'JJ'), ('primitive', 'JJ'), ('parameters', 'NNS'), ('at', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('two', 'CD'), ('equilibrium', 'NN'), ('values', 'NNS'), ('satisfy', 'VBP'), ('a', 'DT'), ('condition', 'NN'), ('that', 'WDT'), ('restricts', 'VBZ'), ('the', 'DT'), ('estimator', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('Cobb-Douglas', 'NNP'), ('parameters', 'NNS'), ('to', 'TO'), ('the', 'DT'), ('unit', 'NN'), ('interval', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | Current Population Survey | …the data used contain information on 16 to 24 year olds inclusive from the Outgoing Rotation Group monthly Current Population Survey samples; this age group is the main focus of the research because minimum wage workers are disproportionately younng and if minimum wage effects on welfare were determined to be small for this group of participants, they are likely to be even more insignificant for older individuals. | [('…the', 'NN'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('used', 'VBD'), ('contain', 'NN'), ('information', 'NN'), ('on', 'IN'), ('16', 'CD'), ('to', 'TO'), ('24', 'CD'), ('year', 'NN'), ('olds', 'NNS'), ('inclusive', 'VBP'), ('from', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('Outgoing', 'NNP'), ('Rotation', 'NNP'), ('Group', 'NNP'), ('monthly', 'JJ'), ('Current', 'NNP'), ('Population', 'NNP'), ('Survey', 'NNP'), ('samples', 'VBZ'), (';', ':'), ('this', 'DT'), ('age', 'NN'), ('group', 'NN'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('the', 'DT'), ('main', 'JJ'), ('focus', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('research', 'NN'), ('because', 'IN'), ('minimum', 'JJ'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('workers', 'NNS'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('disproportionately', 'RB'), ('younng', 'JJ'), ('and', 'CC'), ('if', 'IN'), ('minimum', 'JJ'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('effects', 'NNS'), ('on', 'IN'), ('welfare', 'NN'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('determined', 'VBN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('be', 'VB'), ('small', 'JJ'), ('for', 'IN'), ('this', 'DT'), ('group', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('participants', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('they', 'PRP'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('likely', 'JJ'), ('to', 'TO'), ('be', 'VB'), ('even', 'RB'), ('more', 'RBR'), ('insignificant', 'JJ'), ('for', 'IN'), ('older', 'JJR'), ('individuals', 'NNS'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | Current Population Survey | …in September 1996, researchers assume that the market was in a steady state equilibrium at the minimum wag $4.25, which was due to expire at the end of the month; when moving to the new steady state equilibirium associated with the minimum wage of $4.75, there will be some transitional dynamics. to avoid caputring these effects, researchers perform pooled estimation exercises using data from 5 months after the change, when researchers hope the amarket has nearly reached its new steady state equilibrium.; further separation in time between the before and after observations can not be allowed because the minimum wage changes once again on September 1, 1997 and because the model specification allows for no changes in the price level (the change in the Consumer Price Index between September 1996 and February 1997 was about 1.1%). | [('…in', 'JJ'), ('September', 'NNP'), ('1996', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('researchers', 'NNS'), ('assume', Dataset | Current Population Survey | …estimates of primitive parameters, and particularly the bargaining power parameter were found to be highly sensitive to outliers in the wage data and as a result, researchers rounded all wage observations greater than $30 per hour down to $30; no other modifications of duration or wage informatoin were made. | [('…estimates', 'NNS'), ('of', 'IN'), ('primitive', 'JJ'), ('parameters', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('particularly', 'RB'), ('the', 'DT'), ('bargaining', 'NN'), ('power', 'NN'), ('parameter', 'NN'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('found', 'VBN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('be', 'VB'), ('highly', 'RB'), ('sensitive', 'JJ'), ('to', 'TO'), ('outliers', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('and', 'CC'), ('as', 'IN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('result', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('researchers', 'NNS'), ('rounded', 'VBD'), ('all', 'DT'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('observations', 'NNS'), ('greater', 'JJR'), ('than', 'IN'), ('$', '$'), ('30', 'CD'), ('per', 'IN'), ('hour', 'NN'), ('down', 'IN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('$', '$'), ('30', 'CD'), (';', ':'), ('no', 'DT'), ('other', 'JJ'), ('modifications', 'NNS'), ('of', 'IN'), ('duration', 'NN'), ('or', 'CC'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('informatoin', 'NNS'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('made', 'VBN'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | McDonald's CSI | …researchers have opted to approximate the ratio of total wages paid to firm revenues from one large United States corporation, McDonald's; this firm was selcted because it is the largest private sector employer in the United States, so the law of large number results that must be relied upon are appropriate, second, because this firm has a disproportionate number of employees from the age group in which researchers are interested in, i.e. those between the ages of 16 and 24, and third, because McDonald's is one of the few large employers in this sector that reports sufficiently disaggregated information in its consolidate statement of income to allow computation of the number in which researchers are interested. | [('…researchers', 'NNS'), ('have', 'VBP'), ('opted', 'VBN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('approximate', 'VB'), ('the', 'DT'), ('ratio', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('total', 'JJ'), ('wages', 'NNS'), ('paid', 'VBN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('firm', 'VB'), Dataset | Current Population Survey | …for individuals who earned less than $4.25 in September 1996, researchers assigned them a wage of $4.25, the then current minimum, and similarly, researchers assigned all those who were making less than $4.75 an hour in February 1997 a wage rate of $4.75. | [('…for', 'JJ'), ('individuals', 'NNS'), ('who', 'WP'), ('earned', 'VBD'), ('less', 'JJR'), ('than', 'IN'), ('$', '$'), ('4.25', 'CD'), ('in', 'IN'), ('September', 'NNP'), ('1996', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('researchers', 'NNS'), ('assigned', 'VBD'), ('them', 'PRP'), ('a', 'DT'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('$', '$'), ('4.25', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('the', 'DT'), ('then', 'RB'), ('current', 'JJ'), ('minimum', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('similarly', 'RB'), (',', ','), ('researchers', 'NNS'), ('assigned', 'VBD'), ('all', 'PDT'), ('those', 'DT'), ('who', 'WP'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('making', 'VBG'), ('less', 'JJR'), ('than', 'IN'), ('$', '$'), ('4.75', 'CD'), ('an', 'DT'), ('hour', 'NN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('February', 'NNP'), ('1997', 'CD'), ('a', 'DT'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('rate', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('$', '$'), ('4.75', 'CD'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Current Population Survey | … contains hourly wage distributions for individuals 16 to 24 years of age in September 1996 and February 1997. | [('…', 'NN'), ('contains', 'VBZ'), ('hourly', 'JJ'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('distributions', 'NNS'), ('for', 'IN'), ('individuals', 'NNS'), ('16', 'CD'), ('to', 'TO'), ('24', 'CD'), ('years', 'NNS'), ('of', 'IN'), ('age', 'NN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('September', 'NNP'), ('1996', 'CD'), ('and', 'CC'), ('February', 'NNP'), ('1997', 'CD'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | Current Population Survey | …in both September 1996 and February 1997,there are about 5% of individuals that report hourly wage rates below the mandated minimum wage; however this aspect of the wage distribution is neglected as researchers do not allow for measurement error and the model assumes complieance with the law. | [('…in', 'VB'), ('both', 'DT'), ('September', 'NNP'), ('1996', 'CD'), ('and', 'CC'), ('February', 'NNP'), ('1997', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('there', 'EX'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('about', 'IN'), ('5', 'CD'), ('%', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('individuals', 'NNS'), ('that', 'WDT'), ('report', 'VBP'), ('hourly', 'RB'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('rates', 'NNS'), ('below', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('mandated', 'JJ'), ('minimum', 'JJ'), ('wage', 'NN'), (';', ':'), ('however', 'RB'), ('this', 'DT'), ('aspect', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('distribution', 'NN'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('neglected', 'VBN'), ('as', 'IN'), ('researchers', 'NNS'), ('do', 'VBP'), ('not', 'RB'), ('allow', 'VB'), ('for', 'IN'), ('measurement', 'JJ'), ('error', 'NN'), ('and', 'CC'), ('the', 'DT'), ('model', 'NN'), ('assumes', 'VBZ'), ('complieance', 'NN'), ('with', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('law', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Current Population Survey | …in the estimation phase, researchers first round all minimum wages below the minimum wage up to the minimum wage; after this transformation the proportion of the sample at the minimum wage is over 10% in both months so the overprediction at the mass point is not substantial. | [('…in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('estimation', 'NN'), ('phase', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('researchers', 'NNS'), ('first', 'RB'), ('round', 'VBP'), ('all', 'DT'), ('minimum', 'JJ'), ('wages', 'NNS'), ('below', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('minimum', 'NN'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('up', 'RB'), ('to', 'TO'), ('the', 'DT'), ('minimum', 'JJ'), ('wage', 'NN'), (';', ':'), ('after', 'IN'), ('this', 'DT'), ('transformation', 'NN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('proportion', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('sample', 'NN'), ('at', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('minimum', 'JJ'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('over', 'IN'), ('10', 'CD'), ('%', 'NN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('both', 'DT'), ('months', 'NNS'), ('so', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('overprediction', 'NN'), ('at', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('mass', 'NN'), ('point', 'NN'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('not', 'RB'), ('substantial', 'JJ'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | 1st Wave Interviews | …473 stores in the sample frame had working telephone numbers, and subsequently, these restaurants were called as many as nine times to elicit a response resulting in a total number of completed interviews from 410 of the restaurants, for an overall response rate of 87%. | [('…473', 'NN'), ('stores', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('sample', 'NN'), ('frame', 'NN'), ('had', 'VBD'), ('working', 'VBG'), ('telephone', 'NN'), ('numbers', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('subsequently', 'RB'), (',', ','), ('these', 'DT'), ('restaurants', 'NNS'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('called', 'VBN'), ('as', 'RB'), ('many', 'JJ'), ('as', 'IN'), ('nine', 'CD'), ('times', 'NNS'), ('to', 'TO'), ('elicit', 'VB'), ('a', 'DT'), ('response', 'NN'), ('resulting', 'VBG'), ('in', 'IN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('total', 'JJ'), ('number', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('completed', 'VBN'), ('interviews', 'NNS'), ('from', 'IN'), ('410', 'CD'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('restaurants', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('for', 'IN'), ('an', 'DT'), ('overall', 'JJ'), ('response', 'NN'), ('rate', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('87', 'CD'), ('%', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | 2nd Wave Interviews | …researchers successfully interviewed 371, or 90%, of the 410 stores by phone, however researchers hired an interviewer to drive to each of the 39 nonrespondents and determine whether the store was still open through which it was discovered that six restaurants were permanently closed, two were temporarily closed, and two were under renovation; however, of the 29 stores open for business, all but one granted a request for a personal interview, resulting in a second-wave interview data for 99.8% of the restaurants that responded in the first wave of the survey, and information on closure status for 100% of the sample. | [('…researchers', 'NNS'), ('successfully', 'RB'), ('interviewed', 'VBD'), ('371', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('or', 'CC'), ('90', 'CD'), ('%', Dataset | National Longitudinal Survey of Youth | …the NLSY is not a random sample. Elementary school teachers outnumber secondary school teachers by more than 6:1. Elementary school teachers earn substantially less than other female college graduates: in 1988-91 the average hourly wage of elementary teachers under 34 years old in the CPS is approximately $10.35 per hour, within 23 cents per hour of the wages of NLSY teachers. Because of the disproportionate number of elementary teachers in the data, the results found below may not apply to secondary teachers. | [('…the', 'JJ'), ('NLSY', 'NNP'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('not', 'RB'), ('a', 'DT'), ('random', 'JJ'), ('sample', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('Elementary', 'JJ'), ('school', 'NN'), ('teachers', 'NNS'), ('outnumber', 'VBP'), ('secondary', 'JJ'), ('school', 'NN'), ('teachers', 'NNS'), ('by', 'IN'), ('more', 'JJR'), ('than', 'IN'), ('6:1', 'CD'), ('.', '.'), ('Elementary', 'JJ'), ('school', 'NN'), ('teachers', 'NNS'), ('earn', 'VBP'), ('substantially', 'RB'), ('less', 'JJR'), ('than', 'IN'), ('other', 'JJ'), ('female', 'JJ'), ('college', 'NN'), ('graduates', 'NNS'), (':', ':'), ('in', 'IN'), ('1988-91', 'CD'), ('the', 'DT'), ('average', 'JJ'), ('hourly', 'JJ'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('elementary', 'JJ'), ('teachers', 'NNS'), ('under', 'IN'), ('34', 'CD'), ('years', 'NNS'), ('old', 'JJ'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('CPS', 'NNP'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('approximately', 'RB'), ('$', '$'), ('10.35', 'CD'), ('per', 'IN'), ('hour', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('within', 'IN'), ('23', 'CD'), ('cents', 'NNS'), ('per', 'IN'), ('hour', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('wages', 'NNS'), ('of', 'IN'), ('NLSY', 'NNP'), ('teachers', 'NNS'), ('.', '.'), ('Because', 'IN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('disproportionate', 'JJ'), ('number', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('elementary', 'JJ'), ('teachers', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('data', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('the', 'DT'), ('results', 'NNS'), ('found', 'VBD'), ('below', 'IN'), ('may', 'MD'), ('not', 'RB'), ('apply', 'VB'), ('to', 'TO'), ('secondary', 'JJ'), ('teachers', 'NNS'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | National Longitudinal Survey of Youth | …in the decades 1960 to 1980 the NCES reported a separate category called "fixed costs." The major components in this category were pension and insurance costs. In order to make cost statistics in these years comparable to 1990 statistics, these costs have to be allocated to other current expenditure categories. These costs are divided between instruction, plant operation and maintenance, adminstrative and other school services costs based on the percentage of the total estimated wage bill that these categories represent. | [('…in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('decades', 'NNS'), ('1960', 'CD'), ('to', 'TO'), ('1980', 'CD'), ('the', 'DT'), ('NCES', 'NNP'), ('reported', 'VBD'), ('a', 'DT'), ('separate', 'JJ'), ('category', 'NN'), ('called', 'VBN'), ('``', '``'), ('fixed', 'JJ'), ('costs', 'NNS'), ('.', '.'), ("''", "''"), ('The', 'DT'), ('major', 'JJ'), ('components', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('this', 'DT'), ('category', 'NN'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('pension', 'NN'), ('and', 'CC'), ('insurance', 'NN'), ('costs', 'NNS'), ('.', '.'), ('In', 'IN'), ('order', 'NN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('make', 'VB'), ('cost', 'NN'), ('statistics', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('these', 'DT'), ('years', 'NNS'), ('comparable', 'VBP'), ('to', 'TO'), ('1990', 'CD'), ('statistics', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('these', 'DT'), ('costs', 'NNS'), ('have', 'VBP'), ('to', 'TO'), ('be', 'VB'), ('allocated', 'VBN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('other', 'JJ'), ('current', 'JJ'), ('expenditure', 'NN'), ('categories', 'NNS'), ('.', '.'), ('These', 'DT'), ('costs', 'NNS'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('divided', 'VBN'), ('between', 'IN'), ('instruction', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('plant', 'NN'), ('operation', 'NN'), ('and', 'CC'), ('maintenance', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('adminstrative', 'JJ'), ('and', 'CC'), ('other', 'JJ'), ('school', 'NN'), ('services', 'NNS'), ('costs', 'NNS'), ('based', 'VBN'), ('on', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('percentage', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('total', 'JJ'), ('estimated', 'JJ'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('bill', 'NN'), ('that', 'IN'), ('these', 'DT'), ('categories', 'NNS'), ('represent', 'VBP'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | Current Population Survey | …the sample is restricted to individuals who are either job losers or job leavers, about 60% of unemployment, dropping new entrants and reentrants to the labor force. | [('…the', 'JJ'), ('sample', 'NN'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('restricted', 'VBN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('individuals', 'NNS'), ('who', 'WP'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('either', 'DT'), ('job', 'NN'), ('losers', 'NNS'), ('or', 'CC'), ('job', 'NN'), ('leavers', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('about', 'RB'), ('60', 'CD'), ('%', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('unemployment', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('dropping', 'VBG'), ('new', 'JJ'), ('entrants', 'NNS'), ('and', 'CC'), ('reentrants', 'NNS'), ('to', 'TO'), ('the', 'DT'), ('labor', 'NN'), ('force', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Current Population Survey | …to observe an individual's employment status the following month, the author takes advantage of the fact that the CPS is a rotating panel. Each address is in the survey for four consecutive months, out for eight months, and then in again for four months. Hence, there is a chance to observe the subsequent month emploment status for about three-quarters of the CPS sample. Unfortunately the attrition of households that move or otherwise leave the survey is not representative of the population. | [('…to', 'NN'), ('observe', 'VBP'), ('an', 'DT'), ('individual', 'NN'), ("'s", 'POS'), ('employment', 'NN'), ('status', 'NN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('following', 'VBG'), ('month', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('the', 'DT'), ('author', 'NN'), ('takes', 'VBZ'), ('advantage', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('fact', 'NN'), ('that', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('CPS', 'NNP'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('a', 'DT'), ('rotating', 'JJ'), ('panel', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('Each', 'DT'), ('address', 'NN'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('survey', 'NN'), ('for', 'IN'), ('four', 'CD'), ('consecutive', 'JJ'), ('months', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('out', 'IN'), ('for', 'IN'), ('eight', 'CD'), ('months', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('then', 'RB'), ('in', 'IN'), ('again', 'RB'), ('for', 'IN'), ('four', 'CD'), ('months', 'NNS'), ('.', '.'), ('Hence', 'NNP'), (',', ','), ('there', 'EX'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('a', 'DT'), ('chance', 'NN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('observe', 'VB'), ('the', 'DT'), ('subsequent', 'JJ'), ('month', 'NN'), ('emploment', 'NN'), ('status', 'NN'), ('for', 'IN'), ('about', 'IN'), ('three-quarters', 'NNS'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('CPS', 'NNP'), ('sample', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('Unfortunately', 'RB'), ('the', 'DT'), ('attrition', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('households', 'NNS'), ('that', 'WDT'), ('move', 'VBP'), ('or', 'CC'), ('otherwise', 'RB'), ('leave', 'VBP'), ('the', 'DT'), ('survey', 'NN'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('not', 'RB'), ('representative', 'JJ'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('population', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Current Population Survey | …the procedures and pitfalls for matching observations in the CPS are well-known. The author matches individual records using rotation group, household identifiers, individual line numbers, race, sex, and age. There are a few gaps in the series due to changes in the household identifiers in the public-use files: it is impossible to match data for December 1977/January 1978, June 1985/July 1985, September 1985/October 1985, December 1993/January 1994, and May 1995/June 1995 to August 1995/September 1995. | [('…the', 'NN'), ('procedures', 'NNS'), ('and', 'CC'), ('pitfalls', 'NNS'), ('for', 'IN'), ('matching', 'VBG'), ('observations', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('CPS', 'NNP'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('well-known', 'JJ'), ('.', '.'), ('The', 'DT'), ('author', 'NN'), ('matches', 'NNS'), ('individual', 'JJ'), ('records', 'NNS'), ('using', 'VBG'), ('rotation', 'NN'), ('group', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('household', 'NN'), ('identifiers', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('individual', 'JJ'), ('line', 'NN'), ('numbers', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('race', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('sex', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('age', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('There', 'EX'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('a', 'DT'), ('few', 'JJ'), ('gaps', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('series', 'NN'), ('due', 'JJ'), ('to', 'TO'), ('changes', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('household', 'NN'), ('identifiers', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('public-use', 'JJ'), ('files', 'NNS'), (':', ':'), ('it', 'PRP'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('impossible', 'JJ'), ('to', 'TO'), ('match', 'VB'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('for', 'IN'), ('December', 'NNP'), ('1977/January', 'CD'), ('1978', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('June', 'NNP'), ('1985/July', 'CD'), ('1985', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('September', 'NNP'), ('1985/October', 'CD'), ('1985', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('December', 'NNP'), ('1993/January', 'CD'), ('1994', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('May', 'NNP'), ('1995/June', 'CD'), ('1995', 'CD'), ('to', 'TO'), ('August', 'NNP'), ('1995/September', 'CD'), ('1995', 'CD'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Current Population Survey | …since the redesign of the CPS instrument in 1994, unemployment duration data are often imputed for all workers except those in the first and fifth rotation groups, i.e., those who were not surveyed in the previous month. The author uses data only from these "incoming rotation groups" after 1994, which reduces the sample size by a factor of three. Ultimately, 506,000 records were able to be matched during the 32-year period. | [('…since', 'VB'), ('the', 'DT'), ('redesign', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('CPS', 'NNP'), ('instrument', 'NN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('1994', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('unemployment', 'NN'), ('duration', 'NN'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('often', 'RB'), ('imputed', 'VBN'), ('for', 'IN'), ('all', 'DT'), ('workers', 'NNS'), ('except', 'IN'), ('those', 'DT'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('first', 'JJ'), ('and', 'CC'), ('fifth', 'JJ'), ('rotation', 'NN'), ('groups', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('i.e.', 'FW'), (',', ','), ('those', 'DT'), ('who', 'WP'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('not', 'RB'), ('surveyed', 'VBN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('previous', 'JJ'), ('month', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('The', 'DT'), ('author', 'NN'), ('uses', 'VBZ'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('only', 'RB'), ('from', 'IN'), ('these', 'DT'), ('``', '``'), ('incoming', 'JJ'), ('rotation', 'NN'), ('groups', 'NNS'), ("''", "''"), ('after', 'IN'), ('1994', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('which', 'WDT'), ('reduces', 'VBZ'), ('the', 'DT'), ('sample', 'NN'), ('size', 'NN'), ('by', 'IN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('factor', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('three', 'CD'), ('.', '.'), ('Ultimately', 'RB'), (',', ','), ('506,000', 'CD'), ('records', 'NNS'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('able', 'JJ'), ('to', 'TO'), ('be', 'VB'), ('matched', 'VBN'), ('during', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('32-year', 'JJ'), ('period', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Current Population Survey | …the author weighs observations using the CPS final weights and seasonally adjusts the number of people with duration [tau] with each subsequent employment status using a difference-from-moving average. | [('…the', 'NN'), ('author', 'NN'), ('weighs', 'VBZ'), ('observations', 'NNS'), ('using', 'VBG'), ('the', 'DT'), ('CPS', 'NNP'), ('final', 'JJ'), ('weights', 'NNS'), ('and', 'CC'), ('seasonally', 'RB'), ('adjusts', 'VBZ'), ('the', 'DT'), ('number', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('people', 'NNS'), ('with', 'IN'), ('duration', 'NN'), ('[', 'NNP'), ('tau', 'NN'), (']', 'NN'), ('with', 'IN'), ('each', 'DT'), ('subsequent', 'JJ'), ('employment', 'NN'), ('status', 'NN'), ('using', 'VBG'), ('a', 'DT'), ('difference-from-moving', 'JJ'), ('average', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | Current Population Survey | …annual, state-level data on employment, unemployment, and labor force nonparticipation by gender, age, and education category for individual between the ages of 25 and 64 were calculated using the complete Current Population Survey monthly files for years 1978-1999. The number of observations ranges from 1.1 to 1.3 million annually. Dataset | Current Population Survey | …to attain comparable educational categories across the redefinition of Census's Bureau's education variable introduced in the 1992 CPS, researchers use the method proposed by Jaeger [1997]. In particular, prior to 1992, researchers define high school dropouts as those with fewer than twelve years of completed schooling. In 1993 forward, researchers define high school dropouts as those without a high school diploma or GED certificate. | [('…to', 'NN'), ('attain', 'NN'), ('comparable', 'JJ'), ('educational', 'JJ'), ('categories', 'NNS'), ('across', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('redefinition', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('Census', 'NNP'), ("'s", 'POS'), ('Bureau', 'NNP'), ("'s", 'POS'), ('education', 'NN'), ('variable', 'NN'), ('introduced', 'VBN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('1992', 'CD'), ('CPS', 'NNP'), (',', ','), ('researchers', 'NNS'), ('use', 'VBP'), ('the', 'DT'), ('method', 'NN'), ('proposed', 'VBN'), ('by', 'IN'), ('Jaeger', 'NNP'), ('[', 'NNP'), ('1997', 'CD'), (']', 'NNP'), ('.', '.'), ('In', 'IN'), ('particular', 'JJ'), (',', ','), ('prior', 'RB'), ('to', 'TO'), ('1992', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('researchers', 'NNS'), ('define', 'VBP'), ('high', 'JJ'), ('school', 'NN'), ('dropouts', 'NNS'), ('as', 'IN'), ('those', 'DT'), ('with', 'IN'), ('fewer', 'JJR'), ('than', 'IN'), ('twelve', 'CD'), ('years', 'NNS'), ('of', 'IN'), ('completed', 'VBN'), ('schooling', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('In', 'IN'), ('1993', 'CD'), ('forward', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('researchers', 'NNS'), ('define', 'VBP'), ('high', 'JJ'), ('school', 'NN'), ('dropouts', 'NNS'), ('as', 'IN'), ('those', 'DT'), ('without', 'IN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('high', 'JJ'), ('school', 'NN'), ('diploma', 'NN'), ('or', 'CC'), ('GED', 'NNP'), ('certificate', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Current Population Survey | …for the replacement rate calculations, researchers utilize annual earnings data from the 1964-1999 March CPS Annual Demographic Files and the 1978 CPS Social Security Earnings Records Exact Match file (CPS-SSER). | [('…for', 'VB'), ('the', 'DT'), ('replacement', 'NN'), ('rate', 'NN'), ('calculations', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('researchers', 'NNS'), ('utilize', 'VBP'), ('annual', 'JJ'), ('earnings', 'NNS'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('from', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('1964-1999', 'JJ'), ('March', 'NNP'), ('CPS', 'NNP'), ('Annual', 'NNP'), ('Demographic', 'NNP'), ('Files', 'NNP'), ('and', 'CC'), ('the', 'DT'), ('1978', 'CD'), ('CPS', 'NNP'), ('Social', 'NNP'), ('Security', 'NNP'), ('Earnings', 'NNP'), ('Records', 'NNP'), ('Exact', 'NNP'), ('Match', 'NNP'), ('file', 'NN'), ('(', '('), ('CPS-SSER', 'NNP'), (')', ')'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Current Population Survey | …the Cash Income Replacement Rate equals the ratio of DI benefits in year T + 1 to after-payroll-tax earnings in year T. Calculations for 1999 use the 1965-1999 March CPS files, while the 1979 calculations utilize both the 1964 to 1979 March CPS files and the 1978 CPS-SSER file (for earnings from 1951 -1962). | [('…the', 'JJ'), ('Cash', 'NNP'), ('Income', 'NNP'), ('Replacement', 'NNP'), ('Rate', 'NNP'), ('equals', 'VBZ'), ('the', 'DT'), ('ratio', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('DI', 'NNP'), ('benefits', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('year', 'NN'), ('T', 'NNP'), ('+', 'NNP'), ('1', 'CD'), ('to', 'TO'), ('after-payroll-tax', 'JJ'), ('earnings', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('year', 'NN'), ('T.', 'NNP'), ('Calculations', 'NNP'), ('for', 'IN'), ('1999', 'CD'), ('use', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('1965-1999', 'JJ'), ('March', 'NNP'), ('CPS', 'NNP'), ('files', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('while', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('1979', 'CD'), ('calculations', 'NNS'), ('utilize', 'VB'), ('both', 'DT'), ('the', 'DT'), ('1964', 'CD'), ('to', 'TO'), ('1979', 'CD'), ('March', 'NNP'), ('CPS', 'NNP'), ('files', 'NNS'), ('and', 'CC'), ('the', 'DT'), ('1978', 'CD'), ('CPS-SSER', 'NNP'), ('file', 'NN'), ('(', '('), ('for', 'IN'), ('earnings', 'NNS'), ('from', 'IN'), ('1951', 'CD'), ('-1962', 'NN'), (')', ')'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Current Population Survey | …nonelderly foreign-born populations by state for 1984 and 1998 are estimated using data from the 1980 and 1990 Census of Popuations and the 1998 CPS. Dataset | Survey of Income and Program Participation. | …since SSA does not report the eudcational distribution of DI recipients, researhcers use the Survey of Income and Program Participation to estimate these numbers for 1984 and 1999. SIPP data are unfortunately not available for earlier years. Disability receipt rates by education category, age, and gender were estimated using data from the Survey of Income and Program Participation 1984 wave 1 and 1996 wave 12. A survey respondent is coded as a DI recipient if she "did receive income from Social Security for himself/herself in this month," and her reason for receipt of Social Security was disability. An individual is classified as an SSI recipient if she "did receive any income from Supplemental Security Income for him/herself during the reference period. | [('…since', 'NN'), ('SSA', 'NNP'), Dataset | Exact Match File  | …the relevant wage sample includes all males in the age and education categories regardless of employment status excluding the self-employed (for whom wages are not given in the CPS) those working without pay, and employed workers for whom a wage could not be calculated (due to usual hours reported as variable). | [('…the', 'JJ'), ('relevant', 'JJ'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('sample', 'NN'), ('includes', 'VBZ'), ('all', 'DT'), ('males', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('age', 'NN'), ('and', 'CC'), ('education', 'NN'), ('categories', 'NNS'), ('regardless', 'RB'), ('of', 'IN'), ('employment', 'NN'), ('status', 'NN'), ('excluding', 'VBG'), ('the', 'DT'), ('self-employed', 'JJ'), ('(', '('), ('for', 'IN'), ('whom', 'WP'), ('wages', 'NNS'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('not', 'RB'), ('given', 'VBN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('CPS', 'NNP'), (')', ')'), ('those', 'DT'), ('working', 'VBG'), ('without', 'IN'), ('pay', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('employed', 'VBD'), ('workers', 'NNS'), ('for', 'IN'), ('whom', 'WP'), ('a', 'DT'), ('wage', 'NN'), ('could', 'MD'), ('not', 'RB'), ('be', 'VB'), ('calculated', 'VBN'), ('(', '('), ('due', 'JJ'), ('to', 'TO'), ('usual', 'JJ'), ('hours', 'NNS'), ('reported', 'VBD'), ('as', 'IN'), ('variable', 'JJ'), (')', ')'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Exact Match File  | …wage observations were dropped for which caluclated wages fell outside the range of $1 and $150 per hour (in year 2000 dollars). In cases where state-year-age-education cells were empty, researchers assinged the median value of corresponding nonempty cells. Researchers use fixed age weights corresponding to the share of males (male high school dropouts) in state population in 1984 ages 25 to 34, 35 to 44, 45 to 54, and 55 to 64. Wages are inflated to 2000 values using the chain weighted Personal Consumption Expenditure deflator.  | [('…wage', 'NN'), ('observations', 'NNS'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('dropped', 'VBN'), ('for', 'IN'), ('which', 'WDT'), ('caluclated', 'VBD'), ('wages', 'NNS'), ('fell', 'VBD'), ('outside', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('range', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('$', '$'), ('1', 'CD'), ('and', 'CC'), ('$', '$'), ('150', 'CD'), ('per', 'IN'), ('hour', 'NN'), ('(', '('), ('in', 'IN'), ('year', 'NN'), ('2000', 'CD'), ('dollars', 'NNS'), (')', ')'), ('.', '.'), ('In', 'IN'), ('cases', 'NNS'), ('where', 'WRB'), ('state-year-age-education', 'NN'), ('cells', 'NNS'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('empty', 'JJ'), (',', ','), ('researchers', 'NNS'), ('assinged', 'VBD'), ('the', 'DT'), ('median', 'JJ'), ('value', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('corresponding', 'VBG'), ('nonempty', 'JJ'), ('cells', 'NNS'), ('.', '.'), ('Researchers', 'NNS'), ('use', 'VBP'), ('fixed', 'VBN'), ('age', 'NN'), ('weights', 'NNS'), ('corresponding', 'VBG'), ('to', 'TO'), ('the', 'DT'), ('share', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('males', 'NNS'), ('(', '('), ('male', 'JJ'), ('high', 'JJ'), ('school', 'NN'), ('dropouts', 'NNS'), (')', ')'), ('in', 'IN'), ('state', 'NN'), ('population', 'NN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('1984', 'CD'), ('ages', 'NNS'), ('25', 'CD'), ('to', 'TO'), ('34', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('35', 'CD'), ('to', 'TO'), ('44', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('45', 'CD'), ('to', 'TO'), ('54', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('55', 'CD'), ('to', 'TO'), ('64', 'CD'), ('.', '.'), ('Wages', 'NNS'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('inflated', 'VBN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('2000', 'CD'), ('values', 'NNS'), ('using', 'VBG'), ('the', 'DT'), ('chain', 'NN'), ('weighted', 'VBD'), ('Personal', 'NNP'), ('Consumption', 'NNP'), ('Expenditure', 'NNP'), ('deflator', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | Green Book | …researchers measure UI generosity as the 1984 to 1999 change in the state UI replacement rates for a full-time minimum wage worker using data from the U.S. House of Representatives Green Book. Dataset | Palmer Survey | …the individual-level data come from a study directed by Gladys L. Palmer (1954), with the assistance of the U.S. Bureau of the Census, that assessed labor turnover and geographic mobility in the 1940's. Coded versions of the original schedules, located at the University of Pennsylvania, have been put in machine-readable form. Dataset | Palmer Survey | …the Palmer Survey, funded by the U.S. Air Force, was intended to provide the Air Force with information about manpower requirements in the face of occupational, industrial, and geographic mobility. The population sampling design of the April 1947 Metropolitan Area Surveys of the Burea of the Census was used. Six cities were included for study: two in the East (New Haven and Philadelphia), two in the Midwest (Chicago and St. Paul), and two in the West (Los Angeles and San Francisco). | [('…the', 'JJ'), ('Palmer', 'NNP'), ('Survey', 'NNP'), (',', ','), ('funded', 'VBN'), ('by', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('U.S.', 'NNP'), ('Air', 'NNP'), ('Force', 'NNP'), (',', ','), ('was', 'VBD'), ('intended', 'VBN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('provide', 'VB'), ('the', 'DT'), ('Air', 'NNP'), ('Force', 'NNP'), ('with', 'IN'), ('information', 'NN'), ('about', 'IN'), ('manpower', 'NN'), ('requirements', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('face', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('occupational', 'JJ'), (',', ','), ('industrial', 'JJ'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('geographic', 'JJ'), ('mobility', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('The', 'DT'), ('population', 'NN'), ('sampling', 'VBG'), ('design', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('April', 'NNP'), ('1947', 'CD'), ('Metropolitan', 'NNP'), ('Area', 'NNP'), ('Surveys', 'NNP'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('Burea', 'NNP'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('Census', 'NNP'), ('was', 'VBD'), ('used', 'VBN'), ('.', '.'), ('Six', 'JJ'), ('cities', 'NNS'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('included', 'VBN'), ('for', 'IN'), ('study', 'NN'), (':', ':'), ('two', 'CD'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('East', 'NNP'), ('(', '('), ('New', 'NNP'), ('Haven', 'NNP'), ('and', 'CC'), ('Philadelphia', 'NNP'), (')', ')'), (',', ','), ('two', 'CD'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('Midwest', 'NNP'), ('(', '('), ('Chicago', 'NNP'), ('and', 'CC'), ('St.', 'NNP'), ('Paul', 'NNP'), (')', ')'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('two', 'CD'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('West', 'NNP'), ('(', '('), ('Los', 'NNP'), ('Angeles', 'NNP'), ('and', 'CC'), ('San', 'NNP'), ('Francisco', 'NNP'), (')', ')'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Palmer Survey | …the coded schedules summarize much of the data in the original surveys, and the information they contain can be grouped into two categories: retrospective and contemporaneous. Among the retrospective variables are the occupation and industry of work (if the woman was in the labor force) as of January 1940, December 1944, December 1949, and January 1951. Occupation and industry are also given for the longest job in 1950, the longest job over the work history, the longest job from 1940 to 1949, and the woman's first job. Summary information is provided on months in the labor force from January 1940 to December 1949, the number of jobs during the same period, and the date at which work began prior to 1940. Variables pertaining to the individual as of January 1951, which might be called contemporaneous variables, include weekly earnings at the longest full-time job in 1950 (unless the woman was self-employed), education, marital status, age, number of children less than 18 years of age, years living in the current area, and father's occupation and industry. Some of the contemporaneous variables probably did not change over the preceding decade, but some probably did. | [('…the', 'NN'), ('coded', 'VBD'), ('schedules', 'NNS'), ('summarize', 'VB'), ('much', Dataset | U.S. Bureau of the Census | …the March 1944 census data are used to infer the work histories of women who were not in the labor force during 1950. | [('…the', 'IN'), ('March', 'NNP'), ('1944', 'CD'), ('census', 'NN'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('used', 'VBN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('infer', 'VB'), ('the', 'DT'), ('work', 'NN'), ('histories', 'NNS'), ('of', 'IN'), ('women', 'NNS'), ('who', 'WP'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('not', 'RB'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('labor', 'NN'), ('force', 'NN'), ('during', 'IN'), ('1950', 'CD'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Palmer Survey | …the original schedules, not all of which have been located, contain detailed work histories. Although many of the coded schedules include transcribed versions of these accounts, they are difficult to read, and only the coded portions have been used here. | [('…the', 'JJ'), ('original', 'JJ'), ('schedules', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('not', 'RB'), ('all', 'DT'), ('of', 'IN'), ('which', 'WDT'), ('have', 'VBP'), ('been', 'VBN'), ('located', 'VBN'), (',', ','), ('contain', 'VB'), ('detailed', 'JJ'), ('work', 'NN'), ('histories', 'NNS'), ('.', '.'), ('Although', 'IN'), ('many', 'JJ'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('coded', 'JJ'), ('schedules', 'NNS'), ('include', 'VBP'), ('transcribed', 'JJ'), ('versions', 'NNS'), ('of', 'IN'), ('these', 'DT'), ('accounts', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('they', 'PRP'), ('are', 'VBP'), ('difficult', 'JJ'), ('to', 'TO'), ('read', 'VB'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('only', 'RB'), ('the', 'DT'), ('coded', 'JJ'), ('portions', 'NNS'), ('have', 'VBP'), ('been', 'VBN'), ('used', 'VBN'), ('here', 'RB'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Palmer Survey | The central issue to address with these data is whether women who entered the labor force during World War II remained employed until 1950, therby becoming the main contributors to the vastly increased labor-force participation of married women across the decade. An alternative scenario is that many women employed during the war left the labor force at its conclusion and that much of the increase in employment between 1940 and 1950 came from a post-war movement of women into the labor force. Part of this issue, that concerning the work histories of women employed as of 1950, can be addressed with the Palmer Survey data; the remaining issues are answered with the 1944 census data. | [('The', 'DT'), ('central', 'JJ'), ('issue', 'NN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('address', 'VB'), ('with', 'IN'), ('these', 'DT'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('whether', 'IN'), ('women', 'NNS'), ('who', Dataset | U.S. Bureau of the Census | The central issue to address with these data is whether women who entered the labor force during World War II remained employed until 1950, therby becoming the main contributors to the vastly increased labor-force participation of married women across the decade. An alternative scenario is that many women employed during the war left the labor force at its conclusion and that much of the increase in employment between 1940 and 1950 came from a post-war movement of women into the labor force. Part of this issue, that concerning the work histories of women employed as of 1950, can be addressed with the Palmer Survey data; the remaining issues are answered with the 1944 census data. | [('The', 'DT'), ('central', 'JJ'), ('issue', 'NN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('address', 'VB'), ('with', 'IN'), ('these', 'DT'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('whether', 'IN'), ('women', 'NNS'), ('who', Dataset | Palmer Survey | …although the entire Palmer Survey includes 4,350 women, about 1,200 were married, white, and between 35 and 64 years old (and, of course, working) in 1950. OF these, fully 52% were also in the 1940 labor force (i.e., employed, unemployed, or in the armed forces in January 1940). That is, more than half of those working in 1950 had also worked prior to America's entry into World War II. | [('…although', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('entire', 'JJ'), ('Palmer', 'NNP'), ('Survey', 'NNP'), ('includes', 'VBZ'), ('4,350', 'CD'), ('women', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('about', 'IN'), ('1,200', 'CD'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('married', 'VBN'), (',', ','), ('white', 'JJ'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('between', 'IN'), ('35', 'CD'), ('and', 'CC'), ('64', 'CD'), ('years', 'NNS'), ('old', 'JJ'), ('(', '('), ('and', 'CC'), (',', ','), ('of', 'IN'), ('course', 'NN'), (',', ','), ('working', 'VBG'), (')', ')'), ('in', 'IN'), ('1950', 'CD'), ('.', '.'), ('OF', 'IN'), ('these', 'DT'), (',', ','), ('fully', 'RB'), ('52', 'CD'), ('%', 'NN'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('also', 'RB'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('1940', 'CD'), ('labor', 'NN'), ('force', 'NN'), ('(', '('), ('i.e.', 'FW'), (',', ','), ('employed', 'VBN'), (',', ','), ('unemployed', 'JJ'), (',', ','), ('or', 'CC'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('armed', 'JJ'), ('forces', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('January', 'NNP'), ('1940', 'CD'), (')', ')'), ('.', '.'), ('That', 'DT'), ('is', 'VBZ'), (',', ','), ('more', 'JJR'), ('than', 'IN'), ('half', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('those', 'DT'), ('working', 'VBG'), ('in', 'IN'), ('1950', 'CD'), ('had', 'VBD'), ('also', 'RB'), ('worked', 'VBN'), ('prior', 'RB'), ('to', 'TO'), ('America', 'NNP'), ("'s", 'POS'), ('entry', 'NN'), ('into', 'IN'), ('World', 'NNP'), ('War', 'NNP'), ('II', 'NNP'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Palmer Survey | …the Palmer Survey also includes labor-force status at the time of enumberation (in January 1951), and the results are very similar to those using the criterion of working during any month in 1950. If anything, the results using January 1951 strengthen the finding of persistence for women who worked since 194. However, note that, in this case, there is a bias against an increase during the December 1944 to January 1951 period. Because all women in the sample worked during some month in 1950, the group working in January 1951 cannot include any woman who entered for the first time in that month. | [('…the', 'JJ'), ('Palmer', Dataset | U.S. Bureau of the Census | …an analysis of labor-force turnover among women during World War II requires additional data (to the Palmer Survey data) concerning those not in the labor force in 1950. Such data are available from a special question asked in the March 1944 precursor to the CPS. At the request of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor, the Bureau of the Census asked women in 1944 what they were doing during the week preceding Pearl Harbor, December 1-6, 1941. The Bureau of the Census chose December 1 through 6, 1941, because it was thought that women would remember what they were doing the week before Pearl Harbor better than any other week just prior to America's entry into World War II. The census data yield labor-force transitions from December 1941 to March 1944, the first two sets of branches in the transition tree. | [('…an', 'JJ'), ('analysis', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('labor-force', 'JJ'), ('turnover', 'NN'), ('among', 'IN'), ('women', 'NNS'), ('during', 'IN'), ('World', 'NNP'), ('War', 'NNP'), ('II', 'NNP'), ('requires', 'VBZ'), ('additional', 'JJ'), ('data', ','), ('the', 'DT'), ('Bureau', 'NNP'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('Census', 'NNP'), ('asked', 'VBD'), ('women', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('1944', 'CD'), ('what', 'WP'), ('they', 'PRP'), ('were', ('1941', 'CD'), ('.', '.'), ('The', 'DT'), ('Bureau', 'NNP'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('Census', 'NNP'), ('chose', 'VBD'), ('December', 'NNP'), ('1', 'CD'), ('through', 'IN'), ('6', 'CD'), (',', Dataset | Palmer Survey | …the Palmer Survey contains information on the distribution of those "in the labor force," that is, "in" during 1951. By distributing the total number of women known to have been in the labor force in 1951 according to the proportions in the Palmer Survey for the four "in" branches, one can easily obtain the entire transition tree. | [('…the', 'JJ'), ('Palmer', 'NNP'), ('Survey', 'NNP'), ('contains', 'VBZ'), ('information', 'NN'), ('on', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('distribution', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('those', 'DT'), ('``', '``'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('labor', 'NN'), ('force', 'NN'), (',', ','), ("''", "''"), ('that', 'WDT'), ('is', 'VBZ'), (',', ','), ('``', '``'), ('in', 'IN'), ("''", "''"), ('during', 'IN'), ('1951', 'CD'), ('.', '.'), ('By', 'IN'), ('distributing', 'VBG'), ('the', 'DT'), ('total', 'JJ'), ('number', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('women', 'NNS'), ('known', 'VBN'), ('to', 'TO'), ('have', 'VB'), ('been', 'VBN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('labor', 'NN'), ('force', 'NN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('1951', 'CD'), ('according', 'VBG'), ('to', 'TO'), ('the', 'DT'), ('proportions', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('Palmer', 'NNP'), ('Survey', 'NNP'), ('for', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('four', 'CD'), ('``', '``'), ('in', 'IN'), ("''", "''"), ('branches', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('one', 'CD'), ('can', 'MD'), ('easily', 'RB'), ('obtain', 'VB'), ('the', 'DT'), ('entire', 'JJ'), ('transition', 'NN'), ('tree', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Palmer Survey | …the linkage of the census data with the Palmer Survey is not without possible biases, and they seem more severe for married women. The Palmer Survey listed a woman's marital status in January 1951 but not in any of the previous years. Young married women in 1951 were likely to have been unmarried in the early 1940's. Because the Women's Bureau data for 1944 are given only for women 20-44 years old and those older, one cannot use older age groups to get around the problem. The only solution is to use the Palmer data for women in a slightly older group: 30-51 years old, rather than 27-51 years old, in 1951. The same problem does not afflict the data for the all-marital-statuses category. In the absence of mortality and immigration, these women form a closed population, and their marital status in any particular year is of no consequence. Other possible biases may stem from the fact that the women in the Palmer Survey were all residents of large cities, while the data in the census are a national sample. This bias would matter only if the distribution among the four "in" branches in 1951 differed by urbanization level. | [('…the', 'JJ'), ('linkage', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('census', 'NN'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('with', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('Palmer', 'NNP'), ('Survey', 'NNP'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('not', 'RB'), ('without', 'IN'), ('possible', 'JJ'), ('biases', 'NNS'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('they', 'PRP'), ('seem', 'VBP'), ('more', 'JJR'), ('severe', 'JJ'), ('for', 'IN'), ('married', 'JJ'), ('women', 'NNS'), ('.', '.'), ('The', 'DT'), ('Palmer', 'NNP'), ('Survey', 'NNP'), Dataset | U.S. Bureau of the Census | …the only document that has more detailed data on the labor-force participation of women in 1944 is Current Population Reports, Series P-50, Number 39 (U.S. Bureau of the Census, 1952). The Bureau released these data in 1951, using its more usual age categories (20-24, 25-34, 35-44, and 45-64 years), when it was reported that the proportion of married women in the labor force had exceeded the peak achieved during World War II. However, these figures were not published along with the information on what the women were doing in the week preceding Pearl Harbor. | [('…the', 'NN'), ('only', 'RB'), ('document', 'NN'), ('that', 'WDT'), ('has', 'VBZ'), ('more', 'JJR'), ('detailed', 'JJ'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('on', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('labor-force', 'JJ'), ('participation', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('women', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('1944', 'CD'), ('is', 'VBZ'), ('Current', 'JJ'), ('Population', 'NNP'), ('Reports', 'NNP'), (',', ','), ('Series', 'NNP'), ('P-50', 'NNP'), (',', ','), ('Number', 'NNP'), ('39', 'CD'), ('(', '('), ('U.S.', 'NNP'), ('Bureau', 'NNP'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('Census', 'NNP'), (',', ','), ('1952', 'CD'), (')', ')'), ('.', '.'), ('The', 'DT'), ('Bureau', 'NNP'), ('released', 'VBN'), ('these', 'DT'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('1951', 'CD'), (',', ','), ('using', 'VBG'), ('its', 'PRP$'), ('more', 'JJR'), ('usual', 'JJ'), ('age', 'NN'), ('categories', 'NNS'), ('(', '('), ('20-24', 'JJ'), (',', ','), ('25-34', 'JJ'), (',', ','), ('35-44', 'JJ'), (',', ','), ('and', 'CC'), ('45-64', 'JJ'), ('years', 'NNS'), (')', ')'), (',', ','), ('when', 'WRB'), ('it', 'PRP'), ('was', 'VBD'), ('reported', 'VBN'), ('that', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('proportion', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('married', 'JJ'), ('women', 'NNS'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('labor', 'NN'), ('force', 'NN'), ('had', 'VBD'), ('exceeded', 'VBN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('peak', 'NN'), ('achieved', 'VBN'), ('during', 'IN'), ('World', 'NNP'), ('War', 'NNP'), ('II', 'NNP'), ('.', '.'), ('However', 'RB'), (',', ','), ('these', 'DT'), ('figures', 'NNS'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('not', 'RB'), ('published', 'VBN'), ('along', 'IN'), ('with', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('information', 'NN'), ('on', 'IN'), ('what', 'WP'), ('the', 'DT'), ('women', 'NNS'), ('were', 'VBD'), ('doing', 'VBG'), ('in', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('week', 'NN'), ('preceding', 'VBG'), ('Pearl', 'NNP'), ('Harbor', 'NNP'), ('.', '.')]

Dataset | Palmer Survey | The Palmer Survey has offered a unique view of the female labor force in World War II but does not enable a direct test of the hypothesis concerning a chnaged ideology. The Palmer Survey data have reinforced the conclusions of a growing literature that wartime work did not by itself greatly increase women's employment. | [('The', 'DT'), ('Palmer', 'NNP'), ('Survey', 'NNP'), ('has', 'VBZ'), ('offered', 'VBN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('unique', 'JJ'), ('view', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('female', 'JJ'), ('labor', 'NN'), ('force', 'NN'), ('in', 'IN'), ('World', 'NNP'), ('War', 'NNP'), ('II', 'NNP'), ('but', 'CC'), ('does', 'VBZ'), ('not', 'RB'), ('enable', 'VB'), ('a', 'DT'), ('direct', 'JJ'), ('test', 'NN'), ('of', 'IN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('hypothesis', 'NN'), ('concerning', 'VBG'), ('a', 'DT'), ('chnaged', 'JJ'), ('ideology', 'NN'), ('.', '.'), ('The', 'DT'), ('Palmer', 'NNP'), ('Survey', 'NNP'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('have', 'VBP'), ('reinforced', 'VBN'), ('the', 'DT'), ('conclusions', 'NNS'), ('of', 'IN'), ('a', 'DT'), ('growing', 'VBG'), ('literature', 'NN'), ('that', 'WDT'), ('wartime', 'JJ'), ('work', 'NN'), ('did', 'VBD'), ('not', 'RB'), ('by', 'IN'), ('itself', 'PRP'), ('greatly', 'RB'), ('increase', 'VBP'), ('women', 'NNS'), ("'s", 'POS'), ('employment', 'NN'), ('.', '.')]
Dataset | Palmer Survey | The Palmer Survey (see Palmer, 1954) is a population-based sample of workers from six cities (Chicago, Los Angeles, Minneapolis, New Haven, Philadelphia, and San Francisco) collected by the U.S. Bureau of the Census to explore labor mobility in the 1940's. It is currently aviable fromt he author as an ASCII or a STATA file and will be eventually archived at ICPSR. The data set contains retrospective work histories, from 1940 to 1950, for 4,350 women who worked full-time at least one month in 1950. The work histories are in summary form, containing information on the employment status, industry, and occupation of the individual in 1940, 1944, 1949, 1950, and 1951 and at the time of her first job. Also included are age, marital status, race, years in area, children under 18 years old, place of birth, relationship to household head, education, and father's occupation and industry. | [('The', Dataset | Current Population Survey | …the main data source for this study is the March CPS Public Use Tapes for 1977-87. The CPS data on individuals are supplemented with aggregate data from a variety of sources described below. From the March CPS tapes, a sample was drawn consisting of all female child care workers between teh ages of 18 and 64 (inclusive) and a random subsample of all other women in the same age range. At most, one woman from a given household was included in the sample. the sample begins with the March 1977 survey because in prior years it is not possible to identify the state of residence of all individuals in the sample, and this information is needed in order to determine the subsidies and regulations to which each woman is subject. Males were excluded fromt he sample because over 95% of child care workers are female. | [('…the', 'NN'), ('main', 'JJ'), ('data', 'NNS'), ('source', 'NN'), ('for', 'IN'), ('this', 'DT'), ('study', Dataset | Current Population Survey | …determining who is a child care worker in the CPS data requires considerable care.
